title: In Fulton v. City of Philadelphia (City), will the Supreme Court rule that the City's requirement that Catholic Social Services (CSS) not discriminate against same-sex couples as a condition for working with the City's foster children is unconstitutional?
preds: I am reasonably certain they will rule against the city, but I am uncertain whether they will even address the question at hand directly.
Cases like this is why conservatives went through such a nasty fight to take over the court.
-9pp. I had previously done poorly on a Supreme Court question, so this decrease hopefully corrects this as well as conveys my opinion that this will resolve YES.
The current supreme court will continue to blurr the  separation church and state
Worth a listen for anyone unsure: https://open.spotify.com/episode/6Nhi2LddD55G9fYUNPVv7n?si=Q4PU6MCjSICvKWsnBWZQQA

I'm confident that the conservative majority will rule in favor of the CSS, providing more religious freedom. Even if middle-man Chief Justice Roberts switches over to rule for the City, that would mean a 5-4 lean on CSS's side, still. There is a chance, however, Barrett rules for City as well, making this a 5-4 on the flipside (toward "liberal" side / the City). There is also a chance that Barrett rules for City and Roberts stays with the "conservatives," still a 5-4 in favor of CSS. Breyer is the next bet to switch over to "conservative" ideology. Kavanaugh is Catholic and one year was the Justice most in line with the majority decisions. Kavanaugh and Roberts generally agree. Roberts and Alito generally agree as well. Thomas seems least likely to switch; he had once aspired to become a Catholic pastor and still abides to his Catholic faith. All said, I say likely YES, but chance all this changes. There may be a chance that the last line of this question description becomes true, which is the following: "If the Court decides this case without addressing this question's particular issue of law, the question will close as "No."

I am raising my forecast slightly to come closer to the crowd. After listening to oral arguments I am not really any more clear about what the court is likely to do. One Justice, and I don't remember who, in the oral argument said that the court has a strict rule that they try to never make constitutional decisions if they can at all avoid it. Many justices expressed that both sides have clear rights in this case. I think they may try to do some kind of compromise which grants both sides some rights and may end up not granting the actual ruling of unconstitutionality. yes the court has a conservative majority but I'm not really sure what that means anymore. Today's conservatives tend to be pretty pro-government.  I'm raising my forecast slightly to come closer to the crowd and because of the seeming conservative majority, but 98% certainty seems way too high.

SCOTUS overturns lower courts about 2/3rds of the time. Justices shift would seem to make this an easy “conservative” ruling. Lots of technical legal issues on both side though so don’t think 90s are justified. Especially given the q can resolve at no even if they overturn the lower court on some other issue.

Roberts-  Unclear
Breyer- City
Alito- CSS

Gorsuch- CSS
Sotomayor- City
Kagan- City
Kavanaugh- CSS
Barrett- Unclear CSS- 4
City- 3
Unclear- 2 (1 likely leaning CSS) it appeared that CSS and the foster parents likely would be able to garner at least five votes for a ruling in their favor, even if it wasn’t clear what the basis for such a ruling might be. A decision in the case is expected sometime next year. https://www.scotusblog.com/2020/11/argument-analysis-justices-sympathetic-to-faith-based-foster-care-agency-in-anti-discrimination-dispute/

I may have been a tad naïve on this one, file it under "if it walks like a duck..."
https://www.vox.com/2020/10/30/21538202/supreme-court-amy-coney-barrett-fulton-philadelphia-religion-lgbtq-discrimination-foster

+10 to match the crowd a bit. I think the conservative framing of this makes it look pretty bad. In my opinion the description below has some factual errors, but I can see conservative justices being sympathetic to this point of view. I believe the errors are that CSS believes it couldn't provide referrals because the laws require each agency to address the suitability of applicants. The city also didn't tell CSS how to interpret Catholic teaching, that's a pretty extreme framing of the facts, but again I can see a conservative court being sympathetic to a religious organization being shut out of foster care due to city requirements. "The case involves Catholic Social Services of Philadelphia, which pioneered care for orphans and foster care in the city. It’s been doing that work for more than a century, and today it partners with foster parents like Sharonell Fulton to care for children. But in 2018, city officials began using their monopoly power over foster care to exclude CSS and foster parents like Fulton from taking in more foster children. City officials took this step because CSS cannot provide written “home study” endorsements for same-sex couples, but instead does something commonly done for secular reasons: provide a referral to help a family find the right agency for them. Even though no same-sex couple ever requested an endorsement from CSS, the city stopped placing children with any of the agency’s families, told CSS how it ought to interpret Catholic teaching and changed its rules to prohibit CSS from continuing to work with the city." From here: https://www.scotusblog.com/2020/08/symposium-amid-polarization-and-chaos-the-court-charts-a-path-toward-peaceful-pluralism/

There are those who dare to suggest that recipients of public benefits, whether cash payments or licenses to operate, should obey the law or find other work.   The federal bench as currently constituted is giving this argument short shrift, except in jurisdictions with judges left over from earlier dispensations.

Not sure on this one, having read the circuit decision it seems to make sense and no holes jump out. But of course I'm not a lawyer so who knows. One possibility i could see is that the laws regulating the foster care system essentially prohibit CSS from doing private foster care, they have to work with the city. And so by prohibiting discrimination against same-sex couples the city is prohibiting CSS from foster care entirely. I think that's a potential angle the court conservatives could take. As others have noted SCOTUS more commonly reverses cases it picks up, otherwise it may not have picked them up in the first place. On the one hand I feel like there aren't many holes for SCOTUS to poke in the case, but on the other hand most cases get reversed, conservatives have a majority on the court, and I'm not a lawyer so I'm sure I'm missing angles that could favor ruling against the city. Balancing that out I think 60% is a decent number. Good discussion of some of the background and related cases: https://www.vox.com/2020/2/25/21150692/supreme-court-religion-discrimination-lgbtq-foster-fulton-philadelphia-first-amendment

This boils down to timing of the decision and the approval of Barrett for the Supreme Court. Starting with the current 8 justices one only has to look to the Hobby Lobby Decision as a good barometer to predict this outcome Thomas, Alito, and Roberts all voted in the majority.  Also remember, Gorsuch penned the lower court's opinion which was ultimately affirmed and recognized 1st amendment rights to corporations; therefore it is not a huge leap to assume that he will side against the City in favor of CSS.  [1]  Given their very recent comments about Obergefell v. Hodges., It can be presumed that Alito and Thomas will maintain their positions and vote in favor of CSS. [2]  Kavanaugh will likely join Alito and Thomas just as he did when dissenting against the denial of the injunction in Calvary Chapel Dayton Valley v. Sisolak et al over Covid-19 restrictions on religious institutions.   This leaves us a 4-4 decision.   Considering oral argument isn't scheduled until November 4 we can presume that it is unlikely that the decision will be handed down prior to Barrett's confirmation.[4]  Therefore knowing basically nothing about Barrett except that she is a Republican nominee we can only assume she will side with the four conservative justices making a 5-4 decision.    [1]https://www.chicagotribune.com/nation-world/ct-supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch-notable-opinions-20170131-story.html
[2] https://www.npr.org/2020/10/05/920416357/justices-thomas-alito-blast-supreme-court-decision-on-gay-marriage-rights
[3] https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/19pdf/19a1070_08l1.pdf
[4] https://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/fulton-v-city-of-philadelphia-pennsylvania/

I have no real idea on how the court is going to rule, although I would guess that with the new appointment to the Supreme Court the court will be more conservative and more likely to find this unconstitutional. However, my primary reasoning in regards to this question is simply the idea that the Supreme Court typically only takes cases that it wants to reverse. If the lower courts are ruling properly than there is no need for them to take their time with it. According to this website, and I don't normally give a lot of credence to snopes, but the stats on this web page show that the SCOTUS reverses about two thirds of the cases they take. The third circuit court of appeals in particular has a 68% reversal of cases accepted by the SCOTUS.
https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/ninth-circuit-court-most-overturned/

The court will shift to the right, but there may be some argument that his particular case is not clear cut how the judges would rule. Barrett is on record as stating:
"While the court has clearly ruled in favor of religious liberty over the past decade, this debate will likely remain central to the justices’ work in the years to come. As soon as this fall, they will hear another Becket case, Fulton v. City of Philadelphia — which will address whether the city can shut down Catholic Social Services’ foster care ministry because the agency, consistent with Catholic beliefs, cannot provide written endorsements of same-sex marriages. If asked, the agency would refer a same-sex couple to one of 29 other agencies, including several with expertise in serving LGBTQ families. But for the city of Philadelphia, this accommodation is not enough. An opinion piece had a view about past ruling that could result in a ruling that it is constitutional:
The court’s recent decisions suggest that in Fulton, too, the justices will encourage religious Americans and those who disagree with them to live and let live. If they do, the justices will hopefully help people on all sides produce a healthier and more respectful political climate."
https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/07/14/supreme-court-wants-religious-americans-those-who-disagree-with-them-live-let-live/ At this time we don't know how a new court will rule until we get a sense of how a Judge Barrett approaches cases.

The 5 judges constituting the originalist side of the court have consistently ruled in favor of religious freedom and deference to sincerely held religious beliefs. In Masterpiece Cake Shop V The Colorado Civil Rights Commission, the courts conservative block clearly demonstrated this view. Furthermore with the death of RBG, and the court set to move further to the originalist camp, I do not see how the court would not rule against the city of Philadelphia in this case.

it's more than likely,  Some questions for the American legal enthusiasts and experts; What is the delay between the date of argument (set for Nov 4th, as per SCOTUSblog) and a ruling?
Do high priority cases often push back other cases?
This should be an easy “no” but with a potential 6-3 edge in right leaning jurist, I can envision an eroding in the separation of church and state.

This case is a bit below is a bit different but it does pertain to religious liberties protected under the constitution. considering the court is probably more right now then in 2014 I would think it would lean toward Fulton in this case.  Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc. ruled that In a 5-4 decision issued June 29, 2014, the Supreme Court ruled in favor of Hobby Lobby in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby. The decision of the Tenth Circuit was affirmed, and the decision of the Third Circuit was reversed and remanded. The majority opinion was written by Justice Samuel Alito, who was joined by Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Antonin Scalia, Anthony Kennedy, and Clarence Thomas.[2][7] The court found that the contraception mandate imposed a significant burden on religious corporations and that it was not the least restrictive means of fulfilling the government's objective of providing women access to free birth control. The court noted that a less restrictive method already existed in the exemption provided to religious nonprofits and that the same exemption should be provided to closely held religious corporations.[2]

Gorsuch, Thomas,  Kavanaugh, Roberts, and the new person would vote yes. 
@oskar_b is well-sourced.

SCOTUS ruling in June 2020 on the larger issue of LGBTQ rights was 6-3 in favor.  While there is some notion the matter will receive different consideration with the nomination of Coney-Barrett, a Catholic, to the SC, the earlier case was decided on a larger than usual 5-4 split. Moreover, the question specifically seeks to know whether the SC will rule on a fairly narrow point - whether it will NOT discriminate as a condition of working with the city.  the interpretations of the facts may result in a finding - even if it is pro-CSS - which would still require assessing the probability as quite low. At the heart of the question, CSS is not being barred from practicing religion, it is barred from providing services as a religious organization.
Propability for not issuing an answer is highly unlikely (see answers before). The recent passing of Ginsburg shifts the religious and political view towards pro religious views.

Although the Supreme Court has ruled that all 50 states must perform and recognize same sex marriages, it has not forced religious employers or organizations to do the same.  In fact, recent Supreme Court rulings in July upheld 2 cases in favor of religious institutions or employers in denying medical care coverage for contraceptives and abortions and in choosing employees under Freedom of Religion.  In this vein, the court will likely rule that the CSS has the right to deny same-sex couples licensing for foster care under their organization.

Well, this one got interesting over the past week!  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideological_leanings_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_justices.  the chart at this link maps out the conservative/liberal tendencies of the justices over time.  With the removal of RBG, the court is clearly more conservative, and thus more likely to support conservative ideals.  Given the way this question is formed, i offer that there is only a 33% chance of it being addressed. Despite the court moving more conservative, it is not largely so, thus reducing that chance of "Yes" below 33%.

With Roberts or without him, one could see at least a 5-4 Yes if this occurs after the addition of Amy Barrett.  If for some reason this gets decided before she is added to the court, it's possible that it does not open that big can of worms related to religion.  SCOTUS sidestepped the constitutional question in Masterpiece with Kennedy focusing on  religious hostility towards the baker citing comments from a member of the Commission.  Roberts went along with that. 
Not sure one could interpret the City's comments in this case which suggested that CCS follow Pope Francis as opposed to the local Bishops on the issue of discrimination could be regarded as hostile.
Depends on the timing of a decision.

In the 2019 term, the SCOTUS heard 56 petitions. They averaged 3.5 months before rendering an opinion, with a range of 1 - 9 months.  Across every November from 2015 through 2019 (SCOTUSblog only goes back to 2015), the SCOTUS heard 50 total petitions  (10, 12, 8, 9, 11).  2 of those resulted in opinions that were delivered after Jul 1st. Reviewing the petitions on the 2020 term, all petitions in the month of October are ones that were rescheduled from the previous year's term. In November, Fulton v Philly is the only petition that is a rescheduled petition. I think its highly unlikely (<0%) that it is rescheduled again. 2 opinions rendered after July 1st out of 50 petitions heard in the last 5 x Novembers = 4% frequency. Thus, 96% chance that Fulton v Philly receives an opinion before July 1st. I'm sure there is a better way other than a frequentest approach, but this is what I'm going with for now. There is uncertainty with the absence of a 9th Justice. I think that how the SCOTUS conducts itself in October will give us a clear read on what to expect for petitions scheduled for November. [1] interactive calendar for future use: https://www.scotusblog.com/events/

One has to ask why they agreed to hear this  case.  Philadelphia and the  3rd circuit properly followed precedent and a 6-2 circuit split is not screaming for immediate resolution.  The only reason  this was taken is to overturn Smith.

If they decide it this year, it's a Yes.  Just not sure they'll get it done by then.
